snippet: Ending months of contentious debate, state and city officials on Saturday announced a deal on how the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s five-year, $29 billion capital budget would be financed.
abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio agrees to significantly increase city's contribution to Metropolitan Transit Authority, ending standoff with Gov Andrew M Cuomo; state insisted city should pay greater share towards system; mayor secures promise that $2.5 billion it has agreed to contribute will not be used solely for MTA upgrades and new projects.

byline.original: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS and ALEXANDER BURNS

lead_paragraph: Ending months of contentious debate, state and city officials on Saturday announced a deal on how the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s five-year, $29 billion capital budget would be financed.

headline.main: New York City and State Reach Agreement on M.T.A. Capital Plan
headline.print_headline: Ending Standoff, New York City and State Agree on Financing for M.T.A. Plan
